description.narrative: Urban resilience is a new and upcoming theme for a number of Oxfam country programmes, regions and affiliates. However, as a Confederation, Oxfam currently lacks a common understanding of urban resilience, and our Theories of Change (TOCs), tools, and approaches remain largely relevant for rural contexts given that it is where the bulk of our existing footprint is. How do we apply Oxfam's resilience definition in urban contexts? How does it look like in urban settings? A number of Oxfam country offices and partners want to engage in a participatory and empowering processes to harvest, co -create, exchange, and use knowledge and embed an appetite for collective learning. This process of generating and sharing knowledge drawn from different experiences and contexts is the basis for cross -regional knowledge exchange. It will engage more staff and partners from other locations who will be invited to join during the process. The rapid urbanization rates and incidence of disasters in many of the regions and countries that we work in is making it imperative for Oxfam to adapt, design and learn about approaches and tools that enable us to be more effective in dealing with urban resilience challenges. Learning on past and present experiences will help us increase quality of programmes and inspire new countries and teams. Kenya program will strengthen understanding of the drivers of inequality and invest in brokering partnerships, convene wider coalitions and strengthen capacity of civil society organisations. The aim is to strengthen accountability and measure dis aggregated changes made in the lives of women and from those in society in general. This list illustrates the range of underlying ToCs informing Oxfam's approach to urban resilience.
